text: hmm hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the
Internet's most active music nerd and
it's album review time active child you
are all I see active child is the
project of singer-songwriter Pat grossie
this is his second LP under the name
this thing pretty much began as an
ethereal bedroom recording project with
a lot of laptop and synthesizer in the
mix and there wasn't really much to
separate it from pretty much everybody
else who was making music in the room
with a laptop and a synthesizer but even
at the start of this project Pat had a
pretty unmistakable vocal very heavenly
very sweet I wasn't surprised to find
that this guy actually has a background
singing in choir when I was reading up a
bit on this project it's one EP and kind
of an entire year later and we've got
this you are all i see and this album
comes with some really big improvements
ambitions and sounds all of these
changes all of these great sounds are
apparent right from the start of the
album with pat's vocals they just sound
like rays of sunshine breaking through
clouds of harp arpeggios these analog
synthesizers kind of starts swelling in
the background and it's given me kind of
an 80s vibe why but overall it's kind of
like a dreamy pop opera a dream popera
it's all very fine and pretty and
delicate a lot like an antony and the
johnsons song but a lot less eccentric
and not implying arts enos in every
direction possible I love the sounds on
the track and most of the sample might
do but it's not like the opener really
has a song that I'm blown away by you
know it's it's it's more like a pile of
really pretty sounds like butterflies
just fluttering about not really a
direction more of a mood but my favorite
two tracks on the album come next and
they stick out like sore thumbs
this LP because they are very very
different they're wrapped up in the same
shimmering and glistening production as
the other tracks on this LP pretty much
the same instrumentation but the
execution is different and that
execution is experimental R&B something
that a fan of the weekend or maybe even
how to dress well could appreciate and I
know I have reviewed albums from those
projects and I didn't really dig them
but I am digging this these tracks just
really have very smooth beats lovesick
lyrics honey-flavored vocals and they're
all just filtered through this active
child lens with lots of atmosphere and
reverb inand pretty acoustic ethereal
instrumentation just swarming around it
like fairies how to dress well is even
on one of these tracks and active child
throws a little bit of a gritty loaf I
ish sound on his voice just kind of
maintain that maintain that same
aesthetic that he had on his full-length
LP but what I love about the sounds here
is that the beats are better the synth
our betters everything is a better sound
I would love to hear these guys
collaborate again in the future maybe on
an EP maybe on an entire full-length I
think that would be amazing active child
departs from the R&B stuff after these
two tracks and that makes me kind of sad
because they're really the high points
of the album I'm not saying the rest of
the tracks are bad they just kind of
evoke different imager you know they
make me kind of feel like I'm floating
through space or ascending to heaven or
listening to something that would be put
on at a cult meeting there are some
tracks on the latter half of this LP I
do love though like High Priestess which
is this very bleak atmosphere kind of
art pop song in the vein of Peter
Gabriel or especially fever ray
considering how many weird chorus
effects are on the vocals on that track
the track way too fast is lyrically as
lovesick as some of the R&B songs on
here but the vocals feel way colder way
more electronic and that's kind of
empowered by a lot of synthesized
zehrs in the background a very steady
rigid beat and the vocal melody sounds a
little bit like something James Blake
would even sing and hearing those really
kind of passionate vocals fed through
the vocoder that active child uses on
that track it's really kind of freaky
it's like hearing a robot trying to a
moat a lot like that movie bicentennial
man with Robin Williams where Robin
Williams is a robot and he wants to
become a human I guess my problem with
the very end of this LP is that active
child in my opinion just kind of runs
out of ideas a little bit and is
recycling them and that doesn't make the
songs terrible to me it just makes them
a little less exciting a little
underwhelming that's all I'm feeling a
decent too strong six on this I liked it
but definitely not in love with it what
do you think of this if you've heard it
